variant.question: The optimum altitude of an aeroplane substantially increases during the cruise because of:

options.text: the fuel consumption of the aircraft.
the moving centre of gravity of the aircraft.
the decreasing temperature of the atmosphere with decreasing altitude.
the decreasing density of the atmosphere with increasing altitude.

variant.question: The optimum altitude may vary during cruise, due to...

options.text: the fuel consumption of the aircraft.
the movement of the centre of gravity.
a decrease in temperature.
less density.

variant.question: Which of the following combinations of factors has the most positive influence on the cruise performance of a single-engined piston aeroplane?

options.text: Low temperature and low altitude.
High temperature and low altitude.
Low temperature and high altitude.
High temperature and high altitude.

variant.question: What factors effect the level off altitude

options.text: Temperature & Power
Drag & Power
Power & Lift
Temperature & Drag

variant.question: Which of the following set of factors could lead to a V2 value which is limited by VMCA?

options.text: Low Take-off Mass, high flap setting and low field elevation.
High Take-off Mass, high flap setting and low field elevation.
Low Take-off Mass, low flap setting and low field elevation.
High Take-off Mass, low flap setting and high field elevation.

variant.question: The speed range between low speed buffet and high speed buffet?

options.text: decreases with increasing mass and increasing altitude.
increases with increasing mass.
is only limiting at low altitudes.
decreases with increasing mass and is independent of altitude.

variant.question:
According to the information in a light aircraft manual, which gives two power settings for cruise, 65% and 75%
 If you fly at 75% instead of 65%

options.text: cruise speed will be higher, fuel consumption will be higher.
cruise speed will be the same, fuel consumption will be the same.
cruise speed will be higher, fuel consumption will be the same.
cruise speed will be higher, fuel consumption will be lower.

variant.question: What factors would cause V2 to be limited by VMCA?

options.text: Combination of the above.
With high pressure.
With low temperature.
Flaps at high settings.

variant.question: Cruise altitude can be increased progressively during the flight due to the...

options.text: fuel consumption.
lower temperature.
movement of the centre of gravity.
lower air density.

variant.question: Optimum altitude can be increased progressively during the flight due to the..

options.text: fuel consumption.
movement of the centre of gravity.
lower temperature.
lower air density.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 032-09.
In the attached figure, why is wind omitted from the graph?

options.text: The data is measured with reference to the air
Wind is only considered when climbing in certain directions
The data is measured with reference to the ground
Wind is automatically incorporated into the graph

variant.question: When does the 2^nd^ climb segment begin?

options.text: At gear up
At acceleration altitude
At VFTO
At 35 ft

variant.question: On a transatlantic flight, the captain asks the First Officer why a final step climb from FL340 to FL380 ten minutes before top of descent might not be an efficient use of the fuel. Select a possible explanation:

options.text: A climb to FL380 might consume more fuel than would be saved by being at the higher altitude for a short period.
The headwind present at FL 340 might be more favourable than the still air conditions at FL380.
Even in still air, cruising at the higher optimum level would decrease the specific range.
There might be stronger tailwinds at FL380.

variant.question: Consider the following scenario, You are flying on a long range flight at your maximum 1.3g altitude and ATC asks you to start an immediate step climb. You are very close to your next waypoint, which requires a 90 degree heading change with a 45 degree angle of bank. How should you reply ATC?

options.text: Unable due to performance.
Request to start the step climb after passing the next waypoint.
Request to start a step climb to our 1g altitude at flight level ___.
Roger, leaving flight level___ and climbing to flight level___.

variant.question: When descending below the optimum altitude for a jet aeroplane at the long range cruise speed

options.text: Mach number decreases.
TAS increases.
Mach number increases.
Mach number remains constant.

variant.question: Under which condition should you fly considerably lower (4 000 ft or more) than the optimum altitude?

options.text: If at the lower altitude either considerably less headwind or considerably more tailwind can be expected.
If at the lower altitude there is less tailwind.
If the maximum altitude is below the optimum altitude.
If at the lower altitude there is a greater headwind.

variant.question: Which of the following statements with regard to the optimum cruise altitude (best fuel mileage) is correct?

options.text: An aeroplane sometimes flies above the optimum cruise altitude, because ATC normally does not allow to fly continuously at the optimum cruise altitude.
An aeroplane always flies on the optimum cruise altitude, because this is most attractive from an economy point of view.
An aeroplane always flies below the optimum cruise altitude, as otherwise Mach buffet can occur.
An aeroplane usually flies above the optimum cruise altitude, as this provides the largest specific range.

variant.question: What determines the maximum flight altitude in the Buffet Onset Boundary graph?

options.text: Aerodynamics
Service ceiling
Theoretical ceiling
Economy

variant.question: An aeroplane is conducting a 6 hour sector flying from North Africa to Europe. The initial cruising altitude is FL340 with the recommended maximum being FL390. Normally the optimum cruising altitude is 500 ft to 2 500 ft below the recommended maximum and the recommended maximum altitude increases by 100 ft for every 10 minutes of flight time as the fuel burns off. On this occasion the FMS computes an optimum altitude of FL340 for the entire flight. What could be the reason for it not recommending a step climb to FL370 or higher?

options.text: The wind component at higher altitudes is less favourable, offsetting the increased fuel burn at the lower altitude.
The FMS has not been programmed properly with the correct aeroplane weights, thus giving inaccurate information.
Normally it is more efficient to stay at lower altitudes to take advantage of a higher TAS for the same Mach number.
The aeroplane is too heavy for any higher altitudes during the course of the flight to allow for a 2 000 ft climb.

variant.question: An aeroplane is conducting a 6 hour sector flying from North Africa to Europe. The initial cruising altitude is FL340 with the recommended maximum being FL390. Normally the optimum cruising altitude is 500 ft to 2 500 ft below the recommended maximum and the recommended maximum altitude increases by 100 ft for every 10 minutes of flight time as the fuel burns off. On this occasion the FMS computes an optimum altitude of FL340 for the entire flight. What would be the reason for it not recommending a step climb to FL370 or higher?

options.text: The wind component at higher altitudes is less favourable, offsetting the increased fuel burn at the lower altitude.
Normally it is more efficient to stay at lower altitudes to take advantage of a higher TAS for the same Mach number.
The aeroplane is too heavy for any higher altitudes during the course of the flight to allow for a 2 000 ft climb.
The FMS has not been programmed properly with the correct aeroplane weights, thus giving inaccurate information.

variant.question: Stepped climbs are used on long-distance flights:

options.text: to fly a profile as close as possible to the optimum altitude as the aeroplane mass reduces.
for piston-engined aeroplanes only not for jet aeroplanes.
only if the headwind is less or the tailwind is greater than forecast at high altitude.
to fly as close to the tropopause as possible.

variant.question: The optimum cruise altitude increases

options.text: if the aeroplane mass is decreased.
if the temperature OAT is increased.
if the aeroplane mass is increased.
if the tailwind component is decreased.

variant.question: Below the optimum cruise altitude...

options.text: the Mach number for long range cruise decreases continuously with decreasing altitude.
the Mach number for long range cruise increases continuously with decreasing altitude.
the IAS for long range cruise increases continuously with decreasing altitude.
the TAS for long range cruise increases continuously with decreasing altitude.

variant.question: What should be avoided if quick turnarounds with short sectors have been planned?

options.text: Rapid exit taxiways.
Slow taxi speeds.
Use of thrust reversers.
Inflight gear extended cooling.

variant.question: Why are step climbs used on long distance flights?

options.text: To fly as close as possible to the optimum altitude as aeroplane mass reduces.
Step climbs are only justified if at the higher altitude less headwind or more tailwind can be expected.
Step climbs do not have any special purpose for jet aeroplanes; they are used for piston engine aeroplanes only.
To respect ATC flight level constraints.

variant.question: What is the reason an aircraft may do a step climb?

options.text: Fuel economy
Time saving
Turbulence avoidance
ATC request

variant.question: For which of the following situations a step climb is recommended ?

options.text: When flying 2 000 ft below the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum range.
When flying below the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum endurance.
When flying 2 000 ft above the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum endurance.
When flying at the optimum altitude in order to optimise maximum range.

variant.question: What happens to the long range cruise speed when descending below the optimum altitude for a jet aeroplane?

options.text: Mach number decreases.
EAS increases.
Mach number increases.
Mach number remains constant.

variant.question: The aeroplane, for which data are provided by the Buffet Onset Boundary Chart, is flying at FL350 through the tropics in the late afternoon. Ahead of the aeroplane is an extended line of thunderstorms. If the 1.4 g buffet range is Mach 0.79 to 0.81, which of the following answers is the most appropriate operational decision?

options.text: Descend to FL330 where the 1.4 g buffet margin is Mach 0.73 to greater than Mach 0.84 and navigate laterally between the thunderstorm cells.
Navigate laterally between the thunderstorm cells, limiting the angle of bank to no more than 30°, which will ensure a buffet margin of Mach 0.67 to greater than Mach 0.84.
Navigate laterally between the thunderstorm cells, ensuring straight and level flight at a load factor of 1, which will ensure a buffet margin of Mach 0.62 to greater than Mach 0.84.
Continueas planned because the threat of stall has already been mitigated against by using the 1.4 g buffet margin.

variant.question: The aeroplane, for which data are provided by the Buffet Onset Boundary Chart, is flying at FL350 through the tropics in the late afternoon. Ahead of the aeroplane is an extended line of thunderstorms. If the 1.4 g buffet range is Mach 0.79 to 0.81, which of the following answers is the most appropriate operational decision?

options.text: Descend to FL330 where the 1.4 g buffet margin is Mach 0.73 to greater than Mach 0.84 and navigate laterally between the thunderstorm cells.
Continueas planned because the threat of stall has already been mitigated against by using the 1.4 g buffet margin.
Navigate laterally between the thunderstorm cells, limiting the angle of bank to no more than 30°, which will ensure a buffet margin of Mach 0.67 to greater than Mach 0.84.
Navigate laterally between the thunderstorm cells, ensuring straight and level flight at a load factor of 1, which will ensure a buffet margin of Mach 0.62 to greater than Mach 0.84.

variant.question: The optimum cruise altitude is

options.text: the pressure altitude at which the best specific range can be achieved.
the pressure altitude at which the speed for high speed buffet as TAS is a maximum.
the pressure altitude up to which a cabin altitude of 8000 ft can be maintained.
the pressure altitude at which the fuel flow is a maximum.

variant.question: Which statement with respect to the step climb is correct?

options.text: Performing a step climb based on economy can be limited by the 1.3 g buffet onset requirements.
A step climb may not be performed unless it is indicated in the filed flight plan.
A step climb provides better economy than a cruise climb.
In principle a step climb is performed immediately after the aircraft has exceeded the optimum altitude.

variant.question: Which statement with respect to the step climb is correct?

options.text: Executing a desired step climb at high altitude can be limited by buffet onset at g-loads larger than 1.
A step climb must be executed immediately after the aeroplane has exceeded the optimum altitude.
A step climb is executed in principle when, just after leveling off, the 1.3 g altitude is reached.
A step climb is executed because ATC desires a higher altitude.

variant.question: A twin engined aeroplane in cruise flight with one engine inoperative has to fly over high ground. In order to maintain the highest possible altitude the pilot should choose:

options.text: the speed corresponding to the maximum value of the lift / drag ratio.
the speed at the maximum lift.
the speed corresponding to the minimum value of lift / drag ratio.
the long range speed.

variant.question: The danger associated with low speed and/or high speed buffet:

options.text: limits the maneuvering load factor at high altitudes.
exists only above MMO.
has to be considered at take-off and landing.
can be reduced by increasing the load factor.

variant.question: The optimum altitude of a jet is going to increase with:

options.text: a decreasing Mach number.
a decreasing headwind.
an increasing airplane mass.
an increasing outside air temperature.

variant.question: The improved climb procedure can be used...

options.text: when the runway is long and to clear distant obstacles.
in conjunction with noise abatement procedure 1, NADP 1.
when the runway is short and to clear nearby obstacles.
to climb to the optimum altitude within the shortest time.

variant.question: A stepped climb procedure is used on long-range flights:

options.text: to remain as close to the optimum altitude as possible or to avoid severe turbulence.
to fly as close to the tropopause as possible.
only if the headwind is less or the tailwind is greater at higher altitudes.
for airplanes with piston engines only, not for jet airplanes.

variant.question: Under what circumstances can the improved climb performance procedure be used?

options.text: If sufficient excess runway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by increasing V2.
If a stopway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by decreasing V1.
If a clearway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by increasing V1.
If a sufficient excess runway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by decreasing V2.

variant.question: Under what circumstances can the improved climb performance procedure be used?

options.text: If sufficient excess runway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by increasing V~2~.
If a clearway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by increasing V~1~.
If a stopway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by decreasing V~1~.
If a sufficient excess runway is available, the climb limited take-off mass and the climb gradient can be increased by decreasing V~2~.

variant.question: The reason for an increase in the optimum altitude during the cruise is?

options.text: Fuel consumption.
Movement of passengers.
Decreasing OAT.
Movement of CG.

variant.question: From the following statements, what is correct about using step climbs?

options.text: Performing a step climb based on economy can be limited by the 1.3 g buffet onset.
Step climbs provide better fuel efficiency than cruise climbs.
Step climbs increase efficiency for turboprops but NOT for turbofan aeroplanes.
Step climbs decrease fuel efficiency but increase performance.

variant.question: When should an aeroplane perform a step climb?

options.text: When approximately 2 000 ft below the optimum altitude, in order to increase range.
Anytime between the top of climb and the top of descent in order to increase fuel mileage.
Anytime between the top of climb and the top of descent, in order to increase endurance.
Whenever possible to keep the cruise altitude close to the optimum altitude, in order to increase endurance.
